Title: The World Wide Web
Text: The World Wide Web was invented _1_ British computer scientist Sir Tim Berners-Lee in 1989. He wrote the first web browser while employed at CERN in Switzerland. The browser was released outside CERN _2_ other research institutions in January 1991, and to the general public in August 1991. The Web has been central to the development _3_ the Information Age.

Title: Jane Austen
Text: Jane Austen was an English novelist known primarily _1_ her six major novels, which interpret, critique and comment upon the British landed gentry. Her plots often explore the dependence of women _2_ marriage in the pursuit of favourable social standing and economic security. Her works critique the novels of sensibility of the second half _3_ the 18th century.

Title: The Telephone
Text: The telephone is a telecommunications device that permits two or more users to conduct a conversation when they are too far apart to be heard directly. Alexander Graham Bell was the first to be granted a United States patent _1_ a device that produced clearly intelligible replication of the human voice. This happened _2_ 1876. The telephone became rapidly indispensable _3_ businesses and households.

Title: Penicillin
Text: Penicillin is a group of antibiotics derived _1_ Penicillium moulds. The discovery of penicillin is attributed to Scottish scientist Alexander Fleming in 1928. He showed that, if Penicillium rubens were grown in the appropriate substrate, it would exude a substance with antibiotic properties, _2_ he dubbed penicillin. This discovery changed the course _3_ medicine.

Title: The Steam Engine
Text: A steam engine is a heat engine that performs mechanical work using steam _1_ its working fluid. The steam engine used boiling water to produce mechanical motion. Thomas Newcomen's atmospheric engine was the first commercially successful engine. Later, James Watt improved _2_ this design. These engines were a critical force _3_ the Industrial Revolution.

Title: Robin Hood
Text: Robin Hood is a legendary heroic outlaw originally depicted in English folklore and subsequently featured in literature and film. According _1_ legend, he was a highly skilled archer and swordsman. He is traditionally depicted dressed in Lincoln green. He is said to have robbed from the rich and given to the poor, alongside his band of Merry Men _2_ Sherwood Forest.

Title: The Tower of London
Text: The Tower of London is a historic castle located on the north bank of the River Thames in central London. It was founded towards the end of 1066 as part of the Norman Conquest of England. The White Tower, _1_ gives the entire castle its name, was built by William the Conqueror. It has served _2_ a prison, an armoury, a treasury, and the home of the Crown Jewels.

Title: James Bond
Text: James Bond is a fictional character created by British journalist and novelist Ian Fleming in 1953. Bond is a Secret Service agent, code number 007, residing _1_ London but active internationally. The character has been adapted for television, radio, comic strip, video games and film. The films are the longest continually running film series _2_ all time.

Title: Edinburgh Castle
Text: Edinburgh Castle is a historic fortress which dominates the skyline of Edinburgh, the capital city of Scotland. It stands _1_ the Castle Rock, which has been occupied by humans since at least the Iron Age. There has been a royal castle on the rock _2_ the reign of David I in the 12th century. It is Scotland's most visited paid tourist attraction.

Title: The Grand National
Text: The Grand National is a National Hunt horse race held annually at Aintree Racecourse in Liverpool, England. First run in 1839, it is a handicap steeplechase run _1_ a distance of about 4 miles and 514 yards. The course features 30 fences. It is the most valuable jump race in Europe and is popular _2_ many people who do not normally watch or bet on horse racing.

Title: Hadrian's Wall
Text: Hadrian's Wall was a defensive fortification in the Roman province of Britannia, begun _1_ AD 122 in the reign of the emperor Hadrian. It ran from the banks of the River Tyne near the North Sea to the Solway Firth on the Irish Sea. It had a stone base and a stone wall. It is the largest Roman archaeological feature _2_ Britain.

Title: Wimbledon
Text: The Championships, Wimbledon, commonly known simply as Wimbledon, is the oldest tennis tournament in the world and is regarded _1_ many as the most prestigious. It has been held at the All England Club in Wimbledon, London, since 1877. It is the only major still played _2_ grass, which is the traditional tennis playing surface.

Title: Banksy
Text: Banksy is a pseudonymous England-based street artist, political activist and film director whose real name and identity remain unconfirmed. His satirical street art and subversive epigrams combine dark humour _1_ graffiti executed in a distinctive stenciling technique. His works of political and social commentary have appeared on streets, walls and bridges _2_ the world.

Title: The Mini
Text: The Mini is a small economy car produced by the English-based British Motor Corporation (BMC) and its successors from 1959 until 2000. The original is considered an icon of 1960s British popular culture. Its space-saving front-wheel drive layout allowed 80 percent of the area of the car's floorpan to be used _1_ passengers and luggage. This influenced a generation _2_ car makers.

Title: Stonehenge
Text: Stonehenge is a prehistoric monument on Salisbury Plain in Wiltshire, England. It consists of an outer ring of vertical sarsen standing stones, each around 13 feet high. Archaeologists believe it was constructed from 3000 BC _1_ 2000 BC. The site and its surroundings were added _2_ UNESCO's list of World Heritage Sites in 1986.

Title: Agatha Christie
Text: Dame Agatha Christie was an English writer known for her sixty-six detective novels and fourteen short story collections. She is particularly famous _1_ her fictional detectives Hercule Poirot and Miss Marple. Guinness World Records lists Christie as the best-selling fiction writer of all time, her novels having sold more _2_ two billion copies.

Title: Harry Potter
Text: Harry Potter is a series of seven fantasy novels written _1_ British author J. K. Rowling. The novels chronicle the lives of a young wizard, Harry Potter, and his friends Hermione Granger and Ron Weasley. The main story arc concerns Harry's struggle _2_ Lord Voldemort, a dark wizard who intends to become immortal.

Title: Big Ben
Text: Big Ben is the nickname for the Great Bell of the striking clock at the north end of the Palace of Westminster in London. The tower is officially known _1_ the Elizabeth Tower. The tower was designed by Augustus Pugin in a neo-Gothic style. When completed in 1859, its clock was the largest and most accurate four-faced striking and chiming clock _2_ the world.

Title: Rolls-Royce
Text: Rolls-Royce is a British luxury car manufacturer. The company was founded in 1904 by Charles Rolls and Henry Royce. They established a reputation _1_ superior engineering and manufacturing quality. The 'Silver Ghost', launched in 1906, was declared 'the best car in the world'. Rolls-Royce cars are known _2_ the 'Spirit of Ecstasy' ornament on the bonnet.

Title: Queen Victoria
Text: Victoria was Queen of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland from 20 June 1837 until her death in 1901. Her reign of 63 years and seven months is known _1_ the Victorian era. It was a period of industrial, political, scientific, and military change within the United Kingdom, and was marked _2_ a great expansion of the British Empire.

Title: Oxford English Dictionary
Text: The Oxford English Dictionary (OED) is the principal historical dictionary of the English language, published by Oxford University Press. It traces the historical development of the English language, providing a comprehensive resource _1_ scholars and academic researchers. Work began on the dictionary in 1857, but it was not until 1884 that it started to be published _2_ unbound fascicles.

Title: Chicken Tikka Masala
Text: Chicken tikka masala is a dish consisting of roasted marinated chicken chunks (chicken tikka) in spiced curry sauce. The curry is usually creamy and orange-coloured. It is widely considered _1_ be a British national dish. Some sources suggest it was created by South Asian chefs living _2_ Great Britain.

Title: The Spitfire
Text: The Supermarine Spitfire is a British single-seat fighter aircraft that was used by the Royal Air Force and other Allied countries before, during, and after World War II. It was the only British fighter produced continuously _1_ the war. The Spitfire remains popular among enthusiasts; nearly 60 remain airworthy, and many more are static exhibits _2_ aviation museums.

Title: Charles Dickens
Text: Charles Dickens was an English writer and social critic. He created some of the world's best-known fictional characters and is regarded _1_ many as the greatest novelist of the Victorian era. His works enjoyed unprecedented popularity during his lifetime, and by the 20th century, critics and scholars had recognised him _2_ a literary genius.

Title: Glastonbury Festival
Text: Glastonbury Festival is a five-day festival of contemporary performing arts that takes place in Pilton, Somerset. In addition _1_ contemporary music, the festival hosts dance, comedy, theatre, circus, cabaret, and other arts. Leading pop and rock artists have headlined, alongside thousands _2_ others appearing on smaller stages.

Title: Black Cabs
Text: Hackney carriages, also known as black cabs, are taxicabs licensed to ply _1_ hire in London. Drivers must pass a test called 'The Knowledge', which requires them to master the geography of London streets. They must verify they can navigate _2_ any two points in Greater London without using a map.

Title: The Union Jack
Text: The national flag of the United Kingdom is the Union Jack, also known as the Union Flag. It consists _1_ the red cross of Saint George (patron saint of England), edged in white, superimposed on the Cross of St Patrick (patron saint of Ireland), which are superimposed on the Saltire of Saint Andrew (patron saint of Scotland). Wales is not represented _2_ the flag.

Title: Cambridge University
Text: The University of Cambridge is a collegiate research university in Cambridge, United Kingdom. Founded in 1209, it is the third-oldest surviving university in the world. The university grew _1_ of an association of scholars who left the University of Oxford after a dispute with the townspeople. It consists _2_ 31 semi-autonomous constituent colleges.

Title: Stonehenge
Text: Stonehenge is a prehistoric monument in Wiltshire, England. It consists of a ring of standing stones, each around 13 feet high. It is set within earthworks in the middle of the most dense complex of Neolithic and Bronze Age monuments in England, including several hundred tumuli (burial mounds). It is managed _1_ English Heritage and owned by the Crown. It is one of the most famous landmarks _2_ the United Kingdom.

Title: Red Double-Decker Bus
Text: The AEC Routemaster is a front-engined double-decker bus that was designed by London Transport. It was introduced in 1956 and became an icon of London. Although they have been withdrawn _1_ regular service, one heritage route still operates. They are characterised by their open rear platform, which allowed passengers to get _2_ and off quickly.

Title: Python Interpreter
Text: The Python interpreter is usually installed as /usr/local/bin/python3 on those machines where it is available. Putting /usr/local/bin in your Unix shell's search path makes it possible to start it _1_ typing the command 'python3' to the shell. Since the choice of the directory where the interpreter lives is an installation option, other places are possible; check with your local Python guru or system administrator. On Windows machines where you have installed Python from the Microsoft Store, the python3.11 command will be available. Typing an end-of-file character (Control-D on Unix, Control-Z on Windows) at the primary prompt causes the interpreter to exit with a zero exit status. If that doesn't work, you can exit the interpreter by _2_ the following command: quit().

Title: Python Lists
Text: Python knows a number of compound data types, used to group together other values. The most versatile is the list, which can be written as a list of comma-separated values (items) between square brackets. Lists might contain items of different types, but usually the items all have the same type. Like strings (and all other built-in sequence types), lists can be indexed and sliced. All slice operations return a new list containing the requested elements. This means that the following slice returns a shallow copy of the list: assignments to slices are also possible, and this can even change the size of the list _1_ clear it entirely.

Title: Defining Functions
Text: We can create a function that writes the Fibonacci series to an arbitrary boundary. The keyword 'def' introduces a function definition. It must be followed _1_ the function name and the parenthesized list of formal parameters. The statements that form the body of the function start at the next line, and must be indented. The first statement of the function body can optionally be a string literal; this string literal is the function's documentation string, or docstring. There are tools which use docstrings to automatically produce online or printed documentation, or to let the user interactively browse through code; it is good practice to include docstrings in code that you write, _2_ make a habit of it.

Title: Python Glossary: Immutable
Text: An object with a fixed value. Immutable objects include numbers, strings and tuples. Such an object cannot be altered. A new object has to be created if a different value has to be stored. They play an important role in places where a constant hash value is needed, for example _1_ a key in a dictionary. Some immutable objects might contain mutable objects (e.g. a tuple containing a list). Note that being immutable is not the same _2_ having an immutable value.

Title: Python Glossary: Argument
Text: A value passed to a function (or method) when calling the function. There are two kinds of argument: keyword argument: an argument preceded by an identifier in a function call or passed as a value in a dictionary preceded by **. Positional argument: an argument that is not a keyword argument. Positional arguments can appear at the beginning of an argument list and/or be passed as elements of an iterable preceded by *. Arguments are assigned to the named local variables in a function body. Assignments performed in the body do not change the values of variables _1_ used in the caller.
